ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: A couple of times throughout the semester, we were able to meet in person, outdoors, with social distancing measures in place.
We had a couple classes outside in person, and students in the class would occasionally meet up in Bass Library to join the seminar from the same room.
There was one class where we met outside, while still using laptops for remote people.
During one class closer to the end of the term, we met in-person on cross campus sitting 6-feet apart and respecting all Covid-19 restrictions.
We had a virtual movie screening each week, along with virtual field trips and an end-of-semester virtual class concert. We also had one in-person class.
In-person seminars and live virtual lectures from guests
There was one day of class for this seminar that was in-person.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to analyze literature, specifically through the focuses of close-reading, comparative literature, and literary theory. I also learned how to read efficiently and quickly, and got exposed to a lot of different artistic mediums such as opera.

I was able to gain a much broader knowledge of classical and jazz music in general with the exposure to all the classic composers. Prof. Skorupa's detailed feedback on papers also significantly helped me improve my writing skills. The works we read, listened to, and watched were also incredible.
Writing skills, critical thinking, close reading, music history, music analysis, comparative literature.
I developed skills in precision and complexity that have developed my abilities as a writer to expand on ideas important for the arguments I present in my papers.

This course greatly broadened my understanding of classical music and its connections with literature. Through lots of interesting readings from Ovid to Toni Morrison, combined with program music, films, lieder, and more, we explored the incredible power of music and the beautiful intermedialities between music, literature, art, and dance. The course also allowed me to improve my writing and close reading, as I received detailed feedback on each of my papers.
I gained an insight into music's unmatched role in literature throughout the centuries as well as the skills to take on other literature courses at Yale.

I developed new knowledge about classical music, literature, and art. After taking this course, I learned how to analyze and close read texts, music, and paintings. Through these close analysis readings, I discovered new insights about the purpose and meaning behind famous works by composers, authors, and artists. These insights led me to think more about the similarities and differences between the past and present to ultimately discover that classical work influences most of today's modern music and literature.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: One of the best qualities of this class was the interdisciplinary nature of the course. We looked at so much: from visual art, to short stories and novels, to poetry, and to orchestral music and opera. It was stimulating to look at all these mediums and analyze them in different ways. Also, the way that Professor Skorupa organizes papers (with an initial then final draft) allows you to get a ton of feedback on your writing and gives you plenty of opportunity to improve. One of the biggest weaknesses was the amount of reading. Since we read so much material in the class, there is a lot of reading, and oftentimes in class we wouldn't even get to all of it. I think if the professor had trimmed down the syllabus a bit, we could've had more detailed and fruitful discussions of the material, rather than skimming through.

Prof Skorupa is one of the kindest, most accommodating professors I've had. Especially given COVID, the uncomfortable transition to online learning, and the stressful election week, she was very flexible with deadlines and always gave us as much help as we needed.

I got a lot of practice with writing and received a good amount of feedback for each of my pieces. I also learned a huge amount about both music and literature from the extremely varied readings we were assigned. The essay topics are also completely open, so you can essentially write about anything that relates to the assigned readings. This can be seen as a good or bad thing depending on how well you can come up with essay topics on your own. I do not think there were too many weaknesses, except perhaps certain works we read could be discussed more, although this might take away from the variety and amount of works we read. There was also a lot of reading assigned each week (sometimes an entire book in a week), but there were also very light weeks during busy times (common midterm weeks).

Strengths: The interaction that is within the course is simply unmatched in any other Yale Course. Professor Skorupa is such a fantastic professor who radiates her love for the subject to all her students. Weaknesses: None.

Professor Skorupa is incredible, and her enthusiasm for music and literature inspired all of us. Class discussions were always interesting and insightful, and I felt that I was part of a wonderful community of first years with similar musical interests. However, while I enjoyed all of the readings, some of the works we looked at did not seem to be particularly relevant to the course. In addition, since there is quite a large quantity of reading, we were not able to fully discuss all of the works that we studied. Overall, I greatly enjoyed the course, and the film screenings, field trips, and class concerts were incredible experiences as well.

Strengths: lively discussions, amazing teacher, just the right amount of challenging assignments, very understanding teacher, great pieces of literature, wonderful and interesting guests from YUAG, the library, etc.

Weaknesses: N/A

The strengths of this course are that it is a small seminar so most of the discussion allows for everyone to have a chance to share their own input. Also, the course has a wide variety of learning experiences ranging from movies, music, readings, and even chances to talk to composers and art curators. There are not many weaknesses I can currently think of that need to be improved.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom tends to lend itself surprisingly well to a discussion-style class, especially by allowing students to mute and unmute so they can speak one at a time to add input to a conversation.

I think overall, this course was successful in including remote and on-campus students. Sometimes, when the on-campus students would meet outside or a few students would meet in a classroom, I (as a remote student) would feel a bit left out. This did not take away from the learning though.

Zoom breakout rooms to aid smaller discussion were terrific during the Covid-19 Pandemic, it allowed students to truly speak and voice their materials that we had covered for homework or in previous classes.

Although they can never compare with the live experience, the virtual film screenings and field trips were organized well and were as successful as they could have been. We also met for an in-person class once on Cross Campus, but the fact that some of our classmates were remote students made the class difficult to organize. The virtual class concert at the end of the semester was really fun and a great way to end the course.
Wonderful engagement of students through Zoom that made students want to participate in class

The course succeeded overall based on the the current COVID-19 pandemic. Most of the discussion from readings were able to occur over zoom easily due to the seminar and discussion format. Also, the extra film screenings were able to succeed most of the time due to the ability to screen share and for the class to watch the movie all at one time. Although the movies would lag at times, they were still functional and able to be seen without much interruption. Despite a lack of in-person contact, the zoom calls and small class allowed for the course to be engaging and for all students to get a chance to discuss their ideas. There are not many practices that need to be improved because most the issues revolve around technology errors.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Any student that is interested in looking at music through an academic lens (especially how it relates to literature) should take this class. Professor Skorupa is a great teacher, and she designs her curriculum in a way that will broaden your knowledge of fine art. I can't recommend this course enough.

Yes! Prof Skorupa is the best, super encouraging, and clearly prioritizes her students learning. However, if you have absolutely no background in music or do not already appreciate classical music, some of the material may be difficult to understand and the readings and other homework may seem a bit boring by nature.

If you would like to improve in writing, while focusing on the topic of music, I definitely recommend this course. You truly do learn to become a better writer by the end of the semester, all while learning a lot about music history, popular themes in music, as well as pure literature.

Yes I would most definitely recommend this course to another colleague. It combines a deeper intellectual understanding of language in music and rhythm in language. If your passions lie within literature and music, this interactive and thought-provoking seminar is for you.

Yes! This would definitely be a great class for someone who is familiar with music theory or just appreciates classical and jazz music. This is a great class to take if you want to improve your writing skills while writing about something that interests you!

I would strongly recommend this course to anyone who enjoys classical music. In addition to lots of interesting ideas about music and literature, the course provides an incredible community of musical first years. The course is also a good choice for anyone looking to improve their writing skills.
Yes!!! If you love classical music and/or jazz, take this course!

Yes! Each week is a new topic which allows you to explore a myriad of topics within the overarching theme of Music and Literature.  There are also a variety of learning formats (from movie nights, to readings, to art gallery visits) to keep the class engaging.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. If you are interested or want to learn more about the topic of the course then definitely shop or take this course. The extra time spent out of class with movie screenings and activities can be a lot, but they are definitely worth it and allow for more insight and applying what you learn from the course to more modern examples outside of a book or classroom. The professor is flexible with scheduling for the class and is responsive to any questions or concerns that come up during the year. Overall, I would recommend this course!
